summary: many reports using a variety of animal models have demonstrated that bone marrow cells (BMCs) may have a role in the repair and regeneration of injured lung, infarcted myocardium, and damaged bone, tendon and cartilage. BMCs cultured in vitro can differentiate into type I, II, and basal and airway epithelial cells and express the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein [9] influenza viruses belong to the family Orthomyxoviridae and cause highly contagious respiratory infections in humans and animals. seasonal influenza epidemics are responsible for between 200,000 and 500,000 influenza-related deaths each year. avian influenza virus has crossed species barrier to infect humans. pigs serve as an excellent animal model to study the pathogenesis of influenza virus. in this study, we report the isolation of previously undocumented progenitor epithelial cells in pig bone marrow that expressed Clara cell secretory protein (Ccsp), a marker for lung progenitor cells. these progenitor cells
